children.text: Content Standard 1.0:  Students sing a varied repertoire of music alone and with others.
Individual Singing Technique
Sing a simple melody with accurate pitch.
Sing independently and expressively.
Sing with technical accuracy and  good breath control throughout their singing ranges.
Perform with technical accuracy and good breath control throughout their singing ranges.
Choral Singing Technique
Sing in an ensemble while following a conductor.
Sing a repertoire of vocal literature in small and large ensembles with expression, technical accuracy, and breath control.
Perform using correct intonation, diction, tone quality, and appropriate expressive qualities in small and large ensembles with and without a conductor.
Independent Part Singing
Sing simple ostinati and two-part  rounds such as Row, Row, Row Your Boat.
Sing descants, partner songs, and three-part rounds.
Sing choral literature written in two and three parts with and without accompaniment.
Perform choral literature written in three/four parts with and without accompaniment.
Variety of Repertoire
Sing patriotic songs, folk songs, and multicultural selections.
Sing more complex patriotic songs, folk songs, and multicultural selections.
Sing music representing diverse genres and styles (e.g. Baroque, classical).
Perform music representing diverse genres and styles.
Content Standard 2.0:  Students perform a varied repertoire of music on instruments alone and with others.
Individual Playing Techniques
Play classroom instruments using proper technique.
Play  rhythmic, melodic, and chordal patterns.
Play with expression and technical accuracy on at least one string, wind, percussion, or classroom instrument.
Perform with expression and technical accuracy on at least one string, wind, percussion, or classroom instrument.
Ensemble Playing Technique
Play in large ensembles demonstrating appropriate ensemble technique while following a conductor.
Play in small and large ensembles demonstrating advanced ensemble technique.
Independent Part Playing
Perform multiple-part ensemble literature.
Perform contrapuntal ensemble literature
Variety of Repertoire
Accompany simple folk, traditional, and multicultural music.
Play or accompany folk, traditional, and multicultural music.
Play a varied repertoire of instrumental literature representing diverse genres and styles.
Perform a large and varied repertoire of instrumental literature representing diverse genres and styles.
Content Standard 3.0:  Students improvise melodies, variations, and accompaniments.
Improvising Rhythms and Melodies
Improvise short melodic and rhythmic patterns.
Improvise melodic and rhythmic patterns within the context of a musical phrase.
Improvise simple melodies.
Improvise complex melodies in a given key.
Improvising Harmonies
Improvise simple harmonies in a given key.
Improvise stylistically appropriate harmonies (e.g. 12-bar blues).
Improvising  Variations
Improvise introductions and codas, B sections, and changing parts of the rondo.
Improvise melodic and rhythmic embellishments on given pentatonic melodies.
Improvise melodic and rhythmic variations on given pentatonic melodies and melodies in major keys.
Content Standard 4.0:  Students compose and arrange music within specified guidelines.
Creating
Create music to interpret stories, rhymes, and poetry.
Create music to interpret  readings or dramatizations.
Composing
Create short songs and instrumental pieces.
Create and perform songs and instrumental pieces.
Compose short pieces using  the elements of music.
Compose music in several distinct styles using the elements of music.
Arranging
Organize pieces using a variety of sound sources.
Organize and perform pieces using a variety of sound sources.
Arrange simple pieces for voices/instruments other than those for which the pieces were originally composed.
Arrange a two-part piece for voices/instruments other than those for which the pieces were originally composed.
Content Standard 5.0:  Students read and notate music.
Rhythmic Reading
Read quarter notes, quarter rests and eighth notes in duple meter.
Read whole, half, dotted half, quarter and eighth notes and rests in duple and triple meter.
Read whole, half, quarter, eighth, sixteenth, and dotted notes,  and rests in 2/4, 3/4, 4/4, 6/8, 3/8, and alla breve meter signatures.
Read complex rhythms in all meters within the context of the repertoire.
Melodic Reading
Read melodic patterns using solfege, numbers and/or letters.
Read melodic patterns in the treble clef  using solfege, numbers  and/or letters.
Read simple melodies in the student's appropriate clef.
Read complex melodies within the context of  the repertoire.
Musical Symbols
Use simple music symbols (e.g. fermata,  repeat signs, and double bar lines).
Use complex music symbols (e.g.  dynamics,  tempo).
Apply music symbols to the repertoire.
Apply standard and nonstandard music symbols within the context of  the repertoire.
Sight Reading
Sight read rhythmic and melodic patterns.
Sight read in unison with technical accuracy and expression.
Sight read in parts with technical accuracy and expression.
Notating
Notate simple rhythmic and melodic patterns (e.g. icons, manipulatives).
Notate simple rhythm and  melody using standard symbols.
Notate simple  musical phrases using standard symbols.
Notate musical phrases using standard and nonstandard symbols (e.g.  used by some 20th century composers).
Content Standard 6.0:  Students listen to, analyze, and describe music.
Analysis of Elements of Music and Performance
Identify simple elements of music.
Compare and contrast simple elements of music when presented aurally.
Apply knowledge of the elements of music in aural examples.
Demonstrate extensive knowledge of the technical vocabulary of the elements of music in analyzing aural examples.
Analysis Within Cultural and Historical Context
Describe the uses of the elements of music in aural examples representing diverse genres and cultures.
Analyze examples of a varied repertoire of music representing diverse genres and cultures by describing the uses of the elements of music and expressive devices.
Content Standard 7.0:  Students evaluate music and music performances.
Developing Musical Criteria
Use criteria to evaluate performances and compositions.
Construct criteria using standard music vocabulary.
Develop musical criteria for evaluating the quality and effectiveness of performances and compositions.
Apply specific musical criteria for making informed critical evaluations of the quality and effectiveness of performance and compositions.
Applying Musical Criteria
Explain personal preferences for specific musical works and styles using simple musical vocabulary  (e.g.  loud/soft;  high/low).
Explain personal preferences for specific musical works and styles using complex musical vocabulary  (e.g.  crescendo/decrescendo;  rondo form).
Evaluate the quality of their own and others' performances and compositions, justifying their opinions.
Apply specific musical criteria in evaluating their own music performances and those of similar or exemplary models.
Content Standard 8.0:  Students demonstrate relationships between music, the other arts, and disciplines outside the arts.
Commonalities Among the Arts
Compare how the characteristics appropriate to each art form can be used to describe similar themes (e.g. motion, inspiration).
Compare how the characteristics appropriate to each art form can be used to describe similar themes and cite examples (e.g. emotion, intensity).
Commonalities Between the Arts and Other Disciplines
Compare concepts common to music and other disciplines outside the arts that are interrelated with those of music (e.g. the Underground Railroad and the use of spirituals for coded escape messages).

Analyze concepts common to music and other disciplines outside the arts  (e.g. conflict resolution:  English - "Romeo and Juliet";  History - The Civil War; Science - chemical reactions;  Music- tension and release).
Content Standard 9.0:  Students demonstrate knowledge of the historical periods and cultural diversity of music.
Cultural and Historical Context
Identify several styles of music from various cultures.
Identify by style aural examples from various historical periods, American musical history, and world cultures.
Describe distinguishing characteristics of representative styles from a variety of historical periods, American musical  history, and world cultures.
Classify music examples by style, historical periods, American musical history, and world cultures.
Role of Music and Musicians
Identify various uses for music in daily experience.
Describe the role of musicians in various settings and cultures  (e.g. performers, educators, critics, composers).
Compare and contrast the roles of musicians and the conditions under which they perform in several world cultures.
Describe various roles that musicians play and cite the achievements of representative individuals.
Content Standard 10.0:  Students demonstrate an understanding of movement through skills, techniques, choreography, and as a form of communication.
Dance / Movement
Using Grade 3 standards adopted for Physical Education, Content Standard 3.0, demonstrate an understanding of the standards.
Using Grade 5 standards adopted for Physical Education, Content Standard 3.0, demonstrate an understanding of the standards.
